title: Growthwheel Business Planning Tool
description: Proposers must show assessors & voters an auditable  business plan, but most do not have business planning experience.

f6_assessments.q0: Whilst his could be useful, this is a marketing plan to sell a licensed product and associated consulting services to project catalyst. If the proposal was to develop a similar tool as open source product that would be different. As it stand this seems too expensive relative to the size of the average proposal in Catalyst and thus cannot scale to the whole prgram.
f6_assessments.q1: As it is selling an established product, there is no reason why this could no be delivered as planned.
f6_assessments.q2: Whist success for growth wheel is the number of users, that's not the same thing as success for the users. How would you measure the impact use of this product would have on users and the community a a whole?

f6_assessments.q0: While there is a connection between this proposal and entrepreneurial skills, it looks more that the proposer is planning to promote services of the company he is working for. And that's completely fine if the community decided to buy these expensive services, but my opinion is that in the current world of open source software a lot of valuable information is free and there are ways to spend Catalyst money more efficiently.
f6_assessments.q1: There are doubts that Funded proposals will want to choose GrowthWheel, as these days there are a lot of the tools in the market, and many of them are free. Even if the Catalyst (so Cardano treasury) covers the costs of GrowthWheel for the Funded projects, there is no guarantee they will be willing to pay such a high consulting fee ($150 per hour is high, and usually startups don't start with taking such expensive consultations).
f6_assessments.q2: The information about GrowthWheel is very limited. I would advise you to put more information about it. Of course you are an expert in GrowthWheel, but I never heard about it (and I read a lot of business literature)

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is for licensing and advisory services for 10 proposals on an existing business planning tool. The solution does not scale at all however the proposal clearly articulates its value proposition
Based upon my experience, I neither agree nor disagree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The solution is an established product so there are no technical issues. It is not clear however how the community would select the 10 proposals that get to use the product.
Based upon my experience, I neither agree nor disagree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The product is already available and can be implemented immediately so no roadmap is necessary other than deciding which proposals get the licenses. There are no success metrics mentioned.
Based upon my experience, I neither agree nor disagree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0: Providing entrepreneurs help on building their projects on their business side it extremely helpful. It seem this tool and organization is well established and helpful.
f6_assessments.q1:
There is not much of active work in this project. It reduces into being a pool of money for 10 arbitrarily taken participants of Catalyst fund to join Growthwheel.
There is no plan to actually work with all fund winners. I believe even a set of lectures(maybe mandatory) for all fund winners would be a more robust plan than being a money pool for some fund winners to take the consulting service.
I wouldn't recommend this project in the state it is currently presented, it is a very vague proposal without helpful measures of success.
f6_assessments.q2:
Measuring signups to Growthwheel is not a measure of success. It doesn't mean anything, what matter is active use. Feedback from participants is great, yet there are no metric on how to quantify it. Having something as tangible as, 80% of people that signup(from catalyst fund) actually recommend this project is at least quantifiable. 
There is no measure of how successful the consulted/tutored teams are doing.
I believe, that for these money pool service. The project needs to be much more specific. Specify which people are going to receive help(everybody is not a good statement). They would need to first start with projects of a specific challenge. Upon successful recommendation, from participants should this project be endowed with larger resources.
At the moment I feel, funds requested do not match the level of preparation of this proposal and are not well enough justified.

f6_assessments.q0: This is an interesting proposal that has some merit in that it has certainly identified a real problem within the Catalyst proposal ecosystem. The lack of a detailed budget is the precise reason many great ideas are not receiving the voter support to further their idea. I am unsure whether this proposal is scalable based on the figures presented but believe with some revision this could be addressed.
f6_assessments.q1: While it appears clear that the proposer has good knowledge of the vehicle Growthwheel, it would have been good to see that certification or examples of previous work with other clients. Without this makes it difficult to know what the community would be getting. Providing evidence of this sort is crucial to successful proposals and gives assessors something to base the prediction of success or otherwise.
f6_assessments.q2: While essentially a fine idea I still feel that the information provided is not sufficient to accurately gauge the success of this proposal. I also feel that the current budget needs revision as it appears expensive and cannot be easily scaled without further funds. Given that it could certainly assist future proposers with their own business plan I would like to see an alternative business plan presented that would be more sustainable.

solution: Growthwheel is a widely used tool for small businesses in the US, Europe, Africa and Asia. Access to these robust tools solves the problem.
experience: I am a certified Growthwheel Consultant. Successful serial entrepreneur and angel investor willing to mentor projects or introduce GW.
